Without prejudices, not even form of subsistence alone, Atsushi wanders dying and starving to save Dazai from drowning. The fateful encounter radically changes the life of the young homeless man, engulfing him in a fantastic and supernatural world.
The story revolves around a private detective agency, made up of researchers specializing in diverse areas and empowered to live up to its status. However, this narrative line is not the focal point of the story, serving only as a link to a main line: a relationship of the members with a Port Mafia.
BungouStray Dogs gives the slayer a fun and interesting mix of drama, comedy, mystery and action. The concept of the series is quite interesting, even if it is something repetitive and much worked in the universe of Japanese animation, it manages to be pleasant and exploited from an unusual point of view within the context.


It is not a dramatic play at its core. There was a clear attempt to make it something more dramatic by highlighting the protagonist's squeamish past, however, the connection to that was not happy with the rest comic storyline. It's an entertaining series with a dose of mystery right for us to see without undue commitment. That is, although it is a work of demography within elements too strong emotional points of view, getting by the bloodiest look.


The demographics helped to reduce censorship, allowing the public to enjoy the full of beautiful battle choreography, shootings and murders. The Bones studio continues to do a good job, so in addition to the dazzling scenes, one of the strengths of the animation, maintained an average fluidity. Nothing is extraordinary from the technical point of view, however, nor can we point out blatant errors in this regard.


The photography and the plans of photos have great moments, especially in the climax of the episodes. Whether it was in the "liberation of power", in the battles or when solving some mystery, an animation could make us drool for more.


The character design was the best of the season. It is strong, with gaudy and striking nuclei that are distinguished from other productions. The visual is careful and a harmony achieved between animation, character drawing and acting voice is simply in the right measure.


The soundtrack varied between rhythms with jazz and electronic traits. It remained original in its production and not generally well placed. The opening and closing themes deserve special mention, being particularly very good.


As expectations for Bungou Stray Dogs appeared to be high. Like every piece of art, an attention and a critical eye on the same intensity, and the judgments overwhelm on all sides. Of course it is not an ideal work, let alone something representative of the genre. However, it can be regarded as a pleasant work of entertainment to watch any kind of expectation, for those who want to laugh while watching a universe shrouded in mystery with interesting characters and fantastic powers. In addition, this series is full of literary references (as characters represent an author and name of their powers over their respective literary works), so for any lover of literature, especially Japanese, or enjoyment is intensified.


However, for those looking for a more "dark" work from an emotional and narrative point of view, this will not be the best choice. It has drama, but poorly explored and above all poorly placed, so I suggest you not start Bungou Stray Dogs to desire a dramatic complexity of quality

Literature Greats turned Superhuman Investigators
Bungou Stray Dogs is by large a character analysis piece with literature greats with superpower going to a huge civil gang wars...and the way LA said it, it's actually a great premise, however...
The plot does tend have small short arcs concerning the investigator's firm's quirky wacky members but as well as Atsushi voiced by Yuto Uemura, Doppo Kunikida voiced by Yoshimasa Hosoya and Osamu Dazai's look at society of their world. Dazai is by the far the most interesting character out of the bunch and his background is told in little snippets giving us his "true" self, Doppo's look at societyas a theme is one of the best looks at the corrupted and unfair world that they live in and Atsushi is the realist in all this and probably the most developed characters from the the wimpy, spineless main protagonist to someone who holds his beliefs of his world of peace in high regard, even if it means he needs to dirty his hands to do it.


Unfortunately aside from those three characters, the other support characters at best get one episode with the main protagonist with little to string them together aside being "support" to Doppo, Atsushi and Dazai with their superpowers. The best connection most of the support characters and minor villains are their connection to their real life literary counterparts and their theming makes them intriguing one-off characters (well most of the villains anyways). LA's favourite character would actually be Atsushi as his character development quite surprised LA to the point of calling him a badass, bouns points for Atsusuhi being an audience surrogate making us relate more to himin his world even more. The only other character LA grown a liking to was Kyouka Izumi voiced by Sumire Moroboshi, reason being her backstory, her being a badass and once her appearance and "arc" happened she(*SPOILERS* not only gave Atsusuhi that push from wimp to badass but gave herself character evolution too!) got something of equal share of screentime with Atsushi.


There is comedic bouts in this anime and really it comes off as a mood whiplash at best especially concerning Dazai's attempted suicides. The comedy does work if it's character jabs or banter but the comedy just doesn't mesh with the very serious plot aside from "cooling down period" before getting back into the action.


The animation by Studio Bones is by in large largely reminiscent to Soul Eater right down to the comedic moments to the highly detailed battle scenes. The animation is highly commendable with no animation derps. LA had no problems with the animation and should praise Bones for the gorgeous animation.


If there was anything at fault in Bungou Stray Dogs that would have to be that the anime's pacing is very slow at first (in order to get used the setting and main cast) but just because it's slow doesn't mean it has a benefit, that being it develops the huge roster of characters at the very least.


The mysteries with this anime however are intriguing and does bring plot twists nonchalantly as possible even giving some of the mysteries answer the whole "red herring supernatural cause but actually not" take on it, which is unique giving us something of vibe to the world Atsushi lives in, the plot twists does it's thing by giving more developments outside of the cast (one episode be damned).


Considering this is the first season and the next season will be released by Fall 2016, this anime's "story" is just getting started however LA will see what the first season did and to be frank, besides the mood whiplash comedy the very slow start, Bungou Stray Dogs, gave us a world of literary greats with superpowers, a brewing civil gang wars and a then wimpy spineless main protagonist turned badass and the main plotline thread still looming. LA would like to continue watching Bungou Stray Dogs only to see what happens next as it left us hanging on a cliffhanger by the finale.

When it comes to studio specialties, Bones is definitely one of those companies who specializes in creating story-based action and excels at doing so, being one of the companies with a relatively consistent track record on the quality of their work in this genre.  So, in comparison to Fullmetal alchemist, Soul Eater, Noragami, and Hitsugi no Chaika, how does their newest adaptation, Bungou Stray Dogs stack up?
Story: Atsushi is...a very unfortunate individual.  After being thrown out of his orphanage because they needed to cut costs and so that they would have one less mouth to feed, he is left homeless, penniless, and virtuallyleft to the vultures due to having nothing to eat for a good many days.  After contemplating suicide, he finds a man just dangling in the river he's sitting next to and decides to save him out of the goodness of his heart, only to try and rob him later.  This man named Dazai is an agent for the Armed Detective Agency, a group of individuals with special powers who act sort of like a special police force for the city and solve cases for various events and going-ons in the city.  And with Atsushi being one of these 'special power' wielders, he is taken in by the Agency to then be thrusted into what sums up to be a mob fight in the city.  


Bungou stray dogs, or Straydogs as I'll be calling this show for the rest of the review, runs on an arcic setup where every few episodes runs with a certain storyline that progressively moves the story forward.  What makes this so beneficial to the story is the fact that the show manages to fulfill a lot of the criteria that is needed in order to aid the audience in knowing what is going on.  Every new story provides movement so the anime never loses momentum, each arc focuses on a specific character in the story that also provides a bit of development to their character, and there is always an aftereffect so that the story will then continue to pick up its pace.  Additionally, there're always more comical moments where the characters show less serious and wacky sides to themselves that adds more to the character and qualities of these characters.  (Also, the action is really well done.  Classic gunfights and street brawls were very visually appealing.)


However, Straydogs does have a few bugs in the mix.  The first of which is with the comedy, where the transition from comedic to serious and vice versa are sometimes extremely choppy and doesn't really flow all that well.  And the second, and biggest problem of Straydogs is Atsushi's backstory.  The show consistently in every arc reminds you that Atsushi was a thrown out orphan, even having a dedicated 2-3 minute scene of Atsushi's internal thoughts that details his internal struggle with finding a place in the world.  And they use this WAY too often.  It's fine that the show expresses Atsushi's internal struggle, but the show hammers it in a bit too much to the point that I was shouting at my screen saying "I get it!  Atsushi was abandoned and thrown out for being unwanted.  Jesus, let's get back to the gunfights and street brawls already!"  Every arc has some portion of it dedicated to this aspect of our main protagonist and while it does diminish as the series goes on, and Atsushi does grow as a character, they still do it regardless where in the series we're in and it's just a bit annoying.  


Overall, Straydogs's story is more or less just a lead-in to the second season coming in the Fall.  The series excels at having the classic gang-like setting with the Agency's rival, the 'Port Mafia' acting as the main antagonist for the series and uses this setting to its advantage by having its mini-arcs feature some gritty and well developed stories that impact our characters with every new episode.  Aside from the constant usage of Atsushi's background information, the story didn't really have many flaws.  It wasn't exactly an extremely compelling story, but it was still enjoyable nonetheless.


Overview:

+ Good use of setting

+ Episodes were more or less a perfect blend of both character and story development

-  Kinda leaves us hanging with the ending (Cause hey look, Season 2)

-  Overuse of Atsushi's orphan backstory


Characters:  The characters of Straydogs are actually quite...interesting.  Every single character who has powers has a very unique name for their respective powers, where each character that the series shows us is a reference to a different novel that exists in the world that depends on the character's nationality.  That being said, onto the analyzations.


Atsushi Nakajima is the main character of Bungou Stray Dogs with the power 'Beast beneath the Moonlight' (A reference to The Moon over the Mountain) who has the ability to turn into a white tiger.  That's...basically all he can do.  Of course he gets added physical ability when he goes tiger but in a nutshell, he turns into a tiger.  Anyway, Atsushi serves as the 'new kid on the block' kind of character as he, like the audience, gets introduced to his coworkers at the Agency and every few episodes or so while also being thrown into various situations that show him the kind of cruel reality the world is.  As mentioned before, his backstory is that he was thrown out of an orphanage (is me repeating this starting to get annoying yet?) and more or less left on the streets to die.  As the series progresses, you can see Atsushi's constant self-victimization die down with every new case he's involved in, which while is more or less a plot device to keep the series going, is nice to see cause it moves his character along and helps him grow with every new case that does get progressively harder with every new situation.  The issue I see with Atsushi's character is not with his character himself, but with what he does to the people he's against.  The entire series tells us that everyone and I mean EVERYONE wants Atsushi cause he's so special or he's so good.  This sparks so reasonable rage to some of the other 'main' antagonists to the story that sorta just want to see him drop dead.  My problem with this is because literally everyone he fights has basically the same reason for hating him specifically, it just sorta feels hollow.  


Then there's Osamu Dazai, who has the ability 'No longer human' (a reference to an actual japanese novel called 'No Longer Human') who can negate any ability with a single touch.  Dazai is...an interesting individual.  His character is that of an overzealous person who finds it his duty to commit suicide, but only the most graceful or beautiful suicide, before promptly deciding that he wants to commit a double suicide with a beautiful woman too.  Safe to say, Dazai serves as not only Atsushi's main mentor in the series, but also as the series' comic relief while possessing a decently cunning and intelligent individual underneath.  Despite being one of the more core characters in the series due to his role in the series and his backstory, there really just isn't much to say about Dazai.  He's more or less just...there, and really doesn't add a whole lot to the series' plotline as a whole.  Sure he has his moments, but compared to other characters, he's just not as important story-wise.


Then there're the other characters in the series.  Because of the way the series structures itself, these characters aren't necessarily background or side characters, but rather characters that belong to different factions.  As such, I'll be going them by faction.


The Armed Detective Agency has quite a...colorful cast.  By colorful, I mean REALLY...WEIRD.   As the main faction of characters that we follow, these are the characters that we follow the most.  Each story arc has Atsushi follow or learn from one or more of the Agency members where we get to know them a little more as characters with the arcs that they are involved with as well as understand their sense of humor cause this group of strange individuals definitely have a lot of different kinds of funny bones.


Then we have the Port Mafia, the most prominent antagonist in this season.  Believing in strength and to use their powers to get what they want, the Port Mafia acts as your stereotypical gang group with lots and lots of murderous intent.  Does that mean they're generic?  No.  The series focuses on a select few members of the Port Mafia for a few episodes and/or focuses on their members (Akutagawa specifically) during certain arc in the series.  While their lack of screentime due to the main brunt of the series focusing on the Agency members kinda hampers on knowing everything about how this organization works, there certainly is a great deal of information that the series was about to give us about our antagonist characters that only helped to serve the series.


Finally, we have The Guild, the third and final faction that only appears in the last few episodes in the series.  Because of Season 2, this faction and its agents were only revealed at the very end of the series so there really isn't much to go off of.  But hey, they seemed interesting.


All in all, the characters of Straydogs were while interesting, have a very...clear flaw to them.  At least to me.  I for the life of me cannot remember at least 90% of the cast.  The show has a lot of characters that they throw into the spotlight during certain arcs and moments in time, and while they are all enjoyable and quite memorable as characters, the show doesn't really do a good job at hammering in their names so, at least for me, I cannot recall many of their names.  (Maybe it's due to the fact that I don't read enough to constitute me knowing the authors that these characters reference...)


Overview:

+ Colorful and diverse cast

+ Character development

-  Atsushi is sort of a plot device for some characters

-  I cannot remember most of their names despite knowing more or less everything else about them


Art: The direction that Bones took for this series is leaning towards a sort of dulled out color scheme and simple yet crisp and concise look on the animation.  The majority of the color scheme is either beige or various colors of white and such.  There's no real pop to the color and is pretty monotone to give this sorta big city sort of look.  (And while I say it's monotone, the muted color scheme actually helps give off that gang-filled city feel.)


The action for the series is pretty fluid and the street brawls and such are only elevated by the various powers and abilities that the character wield and use.  As the series takes heavy inspiration from various books and novels, the series uses a series of rings with text on them to dictate the usage of a power or not.  Effects like these and many other involving the usage of powers make the street brawls even more visually appealing to look at and improved the look of the series overall.


Overview:

+ Dulled color scheme that fit with the series's setting

+ Fluid action

+ Good effects to bring more life into the action sequences


Sound:  The OP known as 'Trash Candy' (Weird name, I know) is an rock song that brings a loud and rambunctious tone akin to the city and action theme that the series brings a lot of throughout its entire runtime while the ED, "Namae wo Yobu yo" is a mellow and quiet slow rock piece that pertains more to the metal thoughts and internal conflict with the characters in the series.  Both tracks fit with different aspects to the series and are very well made.  Despite that, these tracks don't...really resonate with me personally.  They're good, don't get me wrong, but just personally, I just don't find these songs to be memorable or worth listening to in my down time unlike a lot of other tracks.  


Overview:

+ Good OST

-  Not really memorable (to me)


Personal Enjoyment: Bones gave me a show a few seasons ago that I absolutely despised.  That show was called Concrete Revolutio.  Because of that, I was actually scared to watch this show because of how similar of a concept that series had with this one.  Nevertheless, my friends tried to convince me that it was nothing like that trash pile and that I would actually see more worth in this series than that one.  So, after finishing this show, I can safely say, dear god they were right.


Did I like this anime?


To say I loved this anime is...a bit overstating it.  This show really isn't the kind of thing I like all too much, but I definitely did enjoy it.  It was consistently interesting and I always appreciate an excessive amount of real life references even if I myself don't get/know of them.  Also, I really like Kyouka.  She's adorable.  


What didn't I like about this anime?


My one and only complaint with this series was how much they drove in the fact that Atsushi or other characters were abandoned by something or someone and were taken in by one of the three factions.  Like seriously, there are an excessive amount of characters that were just recruited off the streets.  It makes sense to have similar backstories so some character can relate to each other, but when you have 3 or more characters like that, well now that's just being a bit excessive, especially with the amount of screentime the show was dedicating just to make sure that you knew that Atsushi was thrown out by the orphanage.  (If I'm saying that too much, the series uses the same 2-3 minute scene at least 5-8 times in the series alone.  Just think about it, about 1/2 episode's worth of screentime is the exact same scene.


Would I recommend this series?


If you want a series that's about gangs and/or gang-related stuff than this series might fit the bill.  The show is largely story-based so there's not a shortage of interesting stuff happening on-screen, and there're enough comedic moments and serious moments to create a good and reasonable balance on both tones of the show.  Overall, Bungou Stray Dogs was a good show that delivered mostly on what it wanted to do.  With a second season coming, the sort of 'read the manga' ending feel doesn't really have any shortcomings as there will be more animated material coming soon, so it also does will in that aspect too.

Let me start by saying that the show was just as bad as the twists that it had. 
The basic premise of the anime is about a group of people with superpowers who solve crimes and help the police. Well, solve is kind of an overstatement, they just have the answer by the end of episode. The logic just doesn't matter nor does evidence. Talking about the story it followed a simple and overused episodic story A along with a main arc story B. The episodic story each had a twist in the end in which the client always turned out to be the culprit.This trope happened in all the episodes. No matter how tough the crime by end of 20 mins all they had to do was to accuse the client and come up with even ridiculous story as an explanation. The only reason I completed the show was because I thought the bigger picture looked interesting, though it too was just like old wine in new glass. Overall, don't expect anything from the story.


If you thought that the story was bad, then characters can only be labelled as worse. There was nothing distinguishing about the characters, they all followed the basic shonen troupes. They were all just a caricatures of basic shonen troupes. There wasn't much of character development, things just happened because someone either yelled at you or someone balanced your shortcomings with their powers. People gained control or discovered extensions of their powers mid battle that helped them to win. Also, no characters had a ulterior motives or ambitions or just anything that fuels a human, they just existed. 


The humor in this anime was so badly placed. It was more forced than the twists. All of the serious moments that could have been a major source for character development was followed by a humor that was neither funny nor a place for it to exist. Bad is just a understatement for the humor. 


The one thing that I liked a lot was the fact the way the superpowers. How they used it was bad but the powers in itself was unique and imaginative. Though the fight scenes were nasty. There was usual hand movements followed by hero getting beaten up, followed by Dazai coming up with a plan (cannot  call it a plan in reality), and then hero beating him up. I literally could not imagine how the author used such great powers so poorly. 


Both art and sound were something I enjoyed in the anime and probably their only saving grace. Both opening and the ending were immensely enjoyable to me. The art suffered here and there and there were some screens of bad animation bu they were minor inconveniences . The character designs were of good quality and the background too were detailed. Overall there shouldn't be anything to complain about in here.


Overall, this anime was disappointing and had nothing new to offer. This anime just follows the long list of anime that used Naruto and the other popular shonen as its role model and blatantly copied it. The story, character, action, and especially the humor were all atrocious. The only good thing was art and sound, though do not expect anything groundbreaking from it too.

How do I start with this show? It was awesome to watch. At first, I was underhyped about this show. It seemed, bland, but boy I was wrong. The story was great with its good, balanced pacing and great character developement. I LOVED the art style to it. I felt it was unique as it has those types of references that can actually teach you things. I did find the slight plot armor a bit annoying in the series, but it was insignificant compared to the excitement in the actual story. I would strongly recomment this anime to many viewers who aren't annoyed by abit of plot armor.

Well. Took me long enough to gather the courage to watch this show. I had seen some clips from the second season, and thought it looked boring. I didn't even bother to try it. But finally, I started the series and really it was worth it!
It tells a comedic, exciting and well-plotted story of people, who have supernatural abilities. You know that's the industry is full of supernatural series, but this is easily one of the best of the whole bunch. It is really special and beautiful series that deserves a spot on my favorites. Every character feels so alive with their creative past andabilities. And there's a lot, I mean A LOT of characters to choose from. Some of the characters relationships and past are twisted and related to each other. And there is even jokes and weird humor put into the episodes! How much can this anime do in only twenty minutes?\n\n
And of course I recommend it. I was truly an outstanding supernatural & mystery series.

Bungou Stray Dogs was an anime I was really excited for, for reasons that weren’t really much. I saw the first PV and just the animations and music alone sold me. I didn’t need to know anything else. After watching the first episode though, well, I have mixed initial reactions. It was a lot more lighthearted than I expected… a lot more. And at first, I had quite a lot of issues in getting used to its tonal shifts. As the series went on, I started to accept both its tone and content. And by the end, I did enjoy the series. Bungou Stray Dogsdoes a lot of things right, in sacrifice for some other qualities. The PVs and key visuals might be misleading with the tone, but the genres aren’t, so you will get what you’ve wanted, just not as much as you’ve wanted.


~{Story}~

Bungou Stray Dogs is about a homeless boy who meet a suicide-loving supernatural detective who makes the boy join his supernatural investigation agency. Yeah, that basically sums it up, though it may not sound too interesting for some. But the series manages to have quite an interesting main story once the mafia aspect gets introduced. The thing is that it’s only interesting when the main story is present. Throughout most of this season, it was mainly episodic supernatural cases that weren’t too enjoyable. They ruined the flow of the series and it’s quite disappointing. And many of these stories were anime-original, so they had no reason to be here. However, when the main story kicks in, it kicks in hard. It’s a very entertaining story about detectives vs. mafias and it manages to be very thrilling… unless if the comedy ruins it (which I’ll talk about later). The story is left incomplete and it ends off at a cliffhanger. This would have been a flaw if a second season wasn’t announced (luckily it’s a split-cour series).

Story: 6.5/10


~{Presentation}~

Bungou Stray Dogs gets a lot of things right, but a lot of things wrong too. The world building in this series is fantastic, as right off the bat, this supernatural, mafia filled world feels believable for some reason. The characters are also presented and introduced nicely, as the series gives adequate development for all of their characters. The series is very stylish and the setting is interesting too. And the fact that all the main characters are named after famous Japanese authors is both weird and enthralling. But the thing Bungou Stray Dogs doesn’t get right is its tone and pacing. Both make the series suffer heavily. The series is a mixture of both comedy and drama, but the mixture isn’t pure enough. Bungou is more relish than ketchup in terms of its mixture. The transition between seriousness to humor to back to seriousness is very off-putting at times. One second the characters will discuss a murder incident, the next second a character will make a joke about committing suicide. The series feels all over the place with its tonal shifts. Secondly, the pacing heavily suffers whenever the main story is put on hold and episodic stories come in. Not much really happens in these 12 episodes. If only the series was a loyal adaptation of the manga.

Presentation: 6/10


~{Character}~

Bungou Stray Dogs has quite a unique set of characters. For many they may end up being likable from the first episode, for others it may take some time, and for some, they may end up not liking them at all. It only took me a second to like the characters in Bungou. Our protagonist, Atsushi, is a very likable main character. He has and interesting power of becoming a tiger spirit and it’s fun seeing his reaction to the other eccentric detectives. And though it may not seem like it at first, but he can be a badass when necessary. He is more than just a pretty face. However, his backstory on why he had to leave his orphanage felt quite weak, though luckily they don’t focus on that too much. Our deuteragonist, Dazai, ended up being my favorite character. He’s character is a good mixture of humor and badass-ness. His committing suicide gag always ended up being funny, even during the umpteenth time. And we have other interesting detectives such as, Edogawa, Kunikida, Miyazawa, Tanizaki and Yosano, whom all are interesting and unique, even if a couple of them borrow some cliché traits. The antagonist of this series, so far, aren’t quite as interesting as the main cast, but they still have another season to shine. 

Character: 7.5/10


~{Art}~, 

It’s really damn pretty, no other way to say it. The lighting, the coloring, the neatness, all amazing. Never was there a drop in detailing. It’s Bones at its best. The character designs are great too. Some may call it fujoshi-bait, but pretty-looking boys doesn’t make the series deserve that title. The backgrounds are pretty too. And those sunsets are absolutely gorgeous. However, whenever a comedic situation happens, the art intentionally looks simplistic and characters are drawn chibi-type. It’s drawn well, but it makes a bad contrast with its more realistic arc. And the simplistic art makes the tonal shift look even more jarring. It almost feels like I’m watching two different anime. Other than the simplistic art, the normal art is gorgeous and is a good competitor for art of the season. 

Art: 8/10


~{Animation}~

Just like its art, Bungou Stray Dogs features great animation too. It’s probably one of the most fluid anime of the season, and it might be better than Bones’s other work from the same season, Boku no Hero Academia (in terms of consistency). Character animations looks superb and the backgrounds are well animated too, especially the wind effects. And during the action moments, the animations look even better and even more fluid. The animations during the chibi/comedic moments are more simplified and it matches the context. It’s just that the comedy itself is a little out-of-place. If there’s nothing you can enjoy from Bungou, at least you have great animations to satisfy you. 

Animation: 8.5/10


~{Voice Acting}~

The seiyuu cast is considerably well-known in Bungou Stray Dogs, and they all do well. Atsushi’s voiced by one of the lesser-known seiyuu, Uemura Yuto, and he does considerably well considering his experience. He manages to do both the lighthearted and the serious moments properly. Saying that Miyano Mamoru didn’t deliver as Dazai is like saying Death Note isn’t the most popular anime of MAL – It’s factually incorrect. Miyano does everything right with Dazai. His humor is on point as it always makes me laugh and his serious moments are fantastic too. His range in his voice is extraordinary and there’s not surprised why he’s loved as a seiyuu so much. And talking about talented seiyuu, Kamiya Hiroshi does Edogawa, and he does it excellently too. However, his character has primarily been in comedic situations, so this anime doesn’t showcase his talent of doing more serious roles, but he still gets the comic timing right. And Kunikida is done well by Hosoya Yoshimasa, as he manages to capture the character’s strict and serious character properly. And you have other talented seiyuu doing supporting roles like Ono Kensho, Sakurai Takahiro, Hanazawa Kana, and Ishikawa Kaito, who all go a good job. 

Voice Acting: 7.5/10


~{Music}~

The thing that made me excited for Bungou Stray Dogs before its premiere was the music. It was good enough for me to quickly put the anime on my “plan-to-watch” list. First of all, Iwasaki Taku is a very talented music composer as he’s done so many well-known tracks for well-known anime. Bungou’s music is an extra addition to his ever-growing list of success. The background music in the series is phenomenal. Some of the jazzy tracks always gets my attention, and the way they are used in the anime, especially during the action scenes, it makes things so much better. Just listen to the music in the first PV and I dare you telling me that it doesn’t sound sexy. The OP, “Trash Candy”, is alright. Personally, it’s not my type of music, but it’s listenable. The music for it is pretty upbeat. The ED, “Namae wo Yobu yo”, is far better as both the vocals and the music is soothing, and it matches the anime too. 

Music: 8.5/10


~{Enjoyment}~

I didn’t enjoy Bungou Stray Dogs as much as I wanted too, due to some noticeable flaws, but there are some things that are done so well that it’s hard not to like it. The premise is interesting and the main plot is great, but whenever the main plot is put on hold for some episodic moments, my enjoyment is put on hold too. And due to large tonal shifts throughout the series, sometimes I feel like I’m being taken away from the moment. Due to tone shifts, comedy moments don’t feel as funny as they should and serious moments lack the punch it needs. But the characters are likable enough for me to get past those issue and still consider this a good series.

Enjoyment: 7/10


In the end, Bungou Stray Dogs is something you should check out for sure. Though it may be a seinen anime, it’s fan base is primarily female based (and it may be due to obvious reasons). Don’t go into this anime with really high expectations because it’s not too special of an anime. And don’t expect the series to be serious focused, because it might just have more comedy than most of the anime from this season. The tonal shifts in the series might be off-putting for some, and it might be the biggest flaw for those who’ve dropped the series. But the characters are likable, and most importantly, memorable, and the story (finally) seems like it’s going somewhere. Though it would have been unforgivable that the series focused on its main story so late, but since the series is a split-cour, it’s hard to complain about it that much. Can’t wait to see how the second season turns out to be. 


+ Great world-building and premise

+ Likable main characters, voiced by talented seiyuu

+ When the main story kicks in, it’s really good

+ Fantastic background music, which complements the action sequences. 

- Some of the episodic storylines ruin the pacing of the series 

- Tonal shifts can be jarring at times and the comedy, at times, is misplaced. 


Overall: 7.4/10

The Lord of anime has graced us yet again with a no more than average creation.Same ol',same ol',I could say.For even if their powers are fairly refreshing,the plot is still ordinary.
Story(7/10)
*I more or less summarize some aspects of the story because I don't want to have to rewatch it again later to remember
I will have mercy in this area because the idea of super powers named after different japanese books and their use appeared curious.But it still managed to dissapoint quite a bit.I can't even remember the characters' names except Dazai and Kyouka so I will look on the info to refresh my mind.Atsushi didn'tstrike me as an too inspiring protagonist.The story begins when he gets kicked out of the orphanage he was in because he was an eyesore and they didn't want the burden of one more child after so many strange attacks at night.After,when he was on the riverbank,he tries to save a drowning man but surprise!He was actually a suicide maniac who would love to die in a double suicide with a beautiful woman.As a reward for ''saving'' Dazai,the MC is given a meal and because he didn't have any place to go to,his future coworker gives him the offer to help at their detective agency.The protagonist was reluctant at first but after some incidents where it proved his worth and that he wouldn't trouble his comrades he decided to stay.But of course things aren't so easy,for he has a huge bounty on his head because of his previously discovered tiger power and the Port Mafia(and some other guys) are hunting him.A few other events lead to another and there are all kinds of cases to solve but the quarells because of Atsushi's power are the center of it all.Oh,and there aren't any particular plot twists so that's a let down...

It ends with the revealing of a quite a peculiar possible villain so I'm wondering if the other season will ultimately save it or destroy it for good because till now it's way too ordinary.


Art(8/10)


The art reminded me of Durarara a bit and I like that.It gets a passing grade from me,even if I love art like the one in Grimgar or Kabaneri more.Their expressions are funny and some of the characters look familliar.For example,Kenji reminds me a lot of Finnian and the girl from the last episode of Grell,both from Black Butler.


Sound(9/10)


This is probably my favorite thing from this show.I just love the way the opening opening starts with Dazai and then introduces the characters and some cool fight scenes.The ending changes in a more tame and sad tone and I could swear there is something going on between Dazai and Atsushi besides the coworker thing.Oh,and I love Ranpo and Dazai's seiyuus.


Character(7/10)


Atsushi has not a such unusual backstory:he has no parents(orphan) and was rejected by the people around him.He doesn't have any big aspirations,just to help the ones in need(like he did with Kyouka) and it's haunted by the same scene over and over again.Dazai is a total mystery besides his weird suicidal tendencies and his later revealed ex-place of work.The others are kind of alright,I like the ''nurse'',she has the most intriguing power in my opinion.But of course I dislike those frickin clingy Tanizaki brothers because of their obvious show of love,incest not being really my thing.And Akutagawa is another one of those disciples thet want to be noticed by senpai but end up with lots of screws loose.


Enjoyment(6/10)


I'm not proud to say this however this has astonished me in any way.My sense of comedy has become Gintama-leveled so nothing less than weird and unbelievable shit can amuse me.As for action,I've seen a lot of it and much of it and this is only acceptable for me.


Overall(7/10)


If you don't have high standards for comedy and action like me and don't mind the absence of plot twists and stuff too deep then I invite to give it a go.Even if only for the awesome op and ed,and boredom it would be a good choice.I sincerely hope the second season will raise to my standards and not let me doze off in my chair

This was a very recreational anime to me as I can watch it casually without feeling the need to fully submerge myself into the story. At first glance, it seemed like this anime was going to be more action built (it still was), but I was surprised at how much dedication they put into building character. Of course some characters were built more in comparison to others, but it was a very interesting thing to watch. I am a bit disappointed that the protagonist wasn't given the opportunity to showcase his ability and I believe this to be because of how far they delayed theopportunities. This caused me to suffice with the other characters' abilities, but it really would have been more satisfying to see the protagonist's in action more often. Overall, interesting anime and would recommend to watch casually.


STORY: 8/10

The typical building up of a protagonist who is a lost soul in their own reality who then comes to terms with their abilities and succeeds in things they never thought possible. Personally, I enjoy these typical build ups, so it fits my standards. Nothing much else to say other than the interesting background the anime gives to certain characters. 


//other ratings are pretty much summarized in the first jumble of text.

Bungou Stray Dogs Season 1 Anime Review
By: Asagiri Kafuka
April 23, 2019
Overall: 10
Plot: 10
It's very rare for me to see an anime where I get really into it only by seeing the first episode. This series is one of them. This story is about gifted human beings with different abilities since they were born. The protagonist found himself alone, dying of hunger. That is when the time a special operative help him and coincidentally the one they are looking for. Along this season, different characters and abilities was introduced. Mainly, it was shown how the protagonist choose to survive on the harsh world he's in withthe people who accept him. It feels like the first season is mainly for introducing every significant characters of the story and the beginning of the war between groups of gifted humans with the principle they have. It seems bias but I really love this anime. 


Characters: 10


I love Dazai. The suicidal maniac who became really serious in times needed. I love this kind of character who is humble and act idiotic, but you know is genius and strong. Apart for him, the other characters have their own unique way of telling that they are also great. They all have different ideals and their actions correspond to that. They stand on their belief and help those in need. It is great how every characters is not perfect, they have flaws, weakness, and mix emotions. Oh. I think, there's one perfect but sulky type out there. 


Sound and Animation: 10


The action scenes on this series is awesome. The way before they displayed or use their skill is one of a kind. And the movement of the characters when they are in a fight is flawless. It was graceful but savage at the same time. Scratches, blood, marks are in there. The emotions of each of them when they are in pain, they are angry, they are serious is perfect. I really like the expression on their faces. You can tell what the characters are feeling the way the level of roughness on their faces changed. As well as the voices which suited their role.


Enjoyment: 10


The first episode sold it to me. It really got me. It made me hook on the series. There are little anime out there who can do the same. The beginning of a story is very important. It is what makes the viewer continue. It is what excites them to turn in the next page. This series does not fail me. Every fights and characters are interesting. The comedy is there. It is a perfect combination.


Ending: 10


The ending is just the beginning. It only get started. The end of the season one is really exciting. It showed the antagonist they will need to face later on the story. The casts are complete so it will be the time to show all the cards. Feels like it. The series will just get more and more interesting. And I can't wait for that!

Bungou Stray Dogs was one of the better anime of this season. Not the best overall but still a decent start to the franchise as a second season is coming out in Fall 2016. I did enjoy this anime for some parts although I myself found this anime quite boring in some episodes.  In my opinion, it will appeal to a lot of people due to its action and decent story. 
Story: 6/10
	The story of Bungou Stray Dogs is decent as of right now. It focuses a lot on our main character, Atsushi becoming a weretiger and how it affects his life. He goesto a detective agency which shelter him from the Port Mafia that are trying to take him because he has a large bounty on his head from all the chaos he has done. Now this anime is just boring for me, It does pick up in the later part of the series, around episode 10 but it is just plain boring before that. Nothing particularly interesting besides the detective scene happens before then and it feels like some of it is filler.  If you can survive that though, the story is more interesting and will surely bring us a treat in the second season. The main problem I have with the story itself is just how boring it can be. It was so hard to just watch it during some scenes because it wasn’t very interesting. It was like watching the first episode of Fate/Zero for the first time and extending that for around 6 episodes. Although the story is unique, the writing just didn’t interest me until 3/4 of the way through this anime. 


Art: 7/10


	The art of Bungou Stray Dogs is good for the most part. It’s not the best by anyone’s standards but it’s not bad at all. Background art looks fine any character designs are good. 


Sound: 7/10


	The sound is solid with a solid Op and decent Ed and it is sometimes nice to hear but there is no stand out track in my opinion and nothing I will remember very well such as Sword Land from SAO or The battle is to the strong from Fate/Zero. Overall, still a solid soundtrack


Characters: 6/10


	The characters to me are sort of interesting but they can honestly be annoying. Dazai to me is interesting but is dragged down by his desire to commit double suicide all the time. Atsushi is always afraid and I really don’t like that about him. Although he can be cool at some moments, he just feels like an average character. Some of the cast can be forgettable while others aren’t. There are some very memorable characters but the others just fade into obscurity for me. I believe they could be better developed too as only Atsushi, Dazia, and Kunikida are actually sort of developed throughout the series. Everyone else has little to no character development. 


Enjoyment: 7/10


	I did enjoy the last part of the series a lot but I did not like the first part of the series. It was boring for me. I did not enjoy the comedy at all during this series either. It isn’t very funny and the dialogue wasn’t very interesting. Action was good but that was really the only thing I enjoyed Bungou Stray Dogs.


Overall: 7/10


	With decent characters and a boring story until the later part of the anime, Bungou Stray Dogs sets itself up for the second season in Fall 2016. Animation and sound are solid and are a nice sized + to this series. Overall, should, you watch Bungou Stray Dogs? Yes, but it may not be for everyone. 


Watch If:

-	You like some good action

-	Liked Kekkai Sensen

-	A more unique spin on Mystery series


Don’t Watch If: 

-	You like comedy (it’s bad)

-	Characters and Story are a priority for you

Spoiler free review everyone! ^^
"There is a way even in difficult times."
I think that's overall the message of this series, and they use a pretty fresh "non-cliche" kind of showing  it to the viewers.
Let's break this diamond into pieces, and I'll tell you some of the hits and misses:
BACKGROUND, STORY AND SETTING: 
The story focus on Atsuhi, a boy that has been kicked out from his orphanage due to a strange reason he still can't comprehend. And thanks to a kind action towars a man with Suicide Tendencies (Dazai) he ends up being involved in a company of supernatural detectives, each with it's owntalent. 

By that t's pretty interenting in it's own. 

The story revolves around a bunch of cases; and every one of those makes you learn a little bit more about the main character and the important side characters. That makes the anime go smooth, without not to much obvious exposition and it's pretty complementary.

What it's good about this anime, is that the min characters have a low of balance between them, and the moral of the good guys and bad guys can be very questionable. And you end up liking both sides.


ART AND SOUNDTRACK: 

Just look at the intro. What I like about Bones studio is that they give each of their animes a pretty "remarkable" artsyle. And this one is full of color without being overwhelming. It's really pleasing to see and eyecatching. That paired up with the awesome rock-electro tipe of music gives you an awesome intro and so much of an aweosme background fighting music. 

As for the ending, it is a huge contrast, being mre calm and story-like.


CHARACTERS: So this is my favorite part to talk when it comes to BSD, cause it is brilliant. For the ones who don't know, every relevant character in the series is named and inspired after a classic (mainly japanese or American) writer. And their powers as well.

Without knowing this the anome is still great to see, but if know this fact and know the authours that inspired this character the anime becomes more interesting and a lot of fun to catch references.

One complain is, that we do not see much character developmet from other characters that are not the main one, and that is kinda sad since the rest of the cast would be so interesting.


TIME RATIO AND EXECUTION:

As I told you, this anime doesn't go on a slow pace, but soemtimes I wished they could explain things a little bit better. I think than even when the motive of the "good guys" it's pretty clear, the one from the bad guys is kinda blurry and not that understandable. You can still figure it out by yourself, which is fun but I would have loved a little bit more depht in that part, and maybe I think that was becuase this season was just 12 episodes.



OVERALL:

Bungou Stray dogs was pretty impressive snce my first impression on this anime was that it was going to be pretty goofy and for comical purposes, but it ended up being more than that, the story is on cliffhanger and I am totally looking forward to see the second part of this o October. If you like omedy, you will like this. If you like action, you will like this.

Reviewing half of a show is tough. Because I know that this show has another half, it’s hard to rate. That being said, I personally think that each season of a show should have a bit of closure, but for the sake of the review and for the show having that other half, I won’t discuss the ending. So let’s see how the 2016 show, Bungou Stray Dogs, fares when looked at it with the critical eye.
Story
The premise of the show goes as follows. Atsushi, an orphan with special powers, gets recruited by a detective agency and fights alongside them. That’s the setup of thisshow and that’s what the first 3 episodes spend their time on. These episodes do a good job introducing the major characters of the series and the main conflict. Although there’s a main conflict in this show, there’s no actual plot. 


It has time progression, but no actual plot. The show likes to go through mini arcs and shows development when that time progresses. How much development is debatable, but there is development nonetheless. With no direction for the series and no end goal, the show gets hit with the problems of poor pacing for time progression, but has good pacing with each episode (most of the time).


Alongside these mini arcs are what boil down to 2 types of episodes: Action oriented conflict episodes and episodes revolved around solving a mystery. One of these types of episodes is good, but the other… not so much. 


The mystery based episodes don’t really give the audience a chance to figure it out because it introduces and solves a mystery in one episode. Not only this, but the episode likes to have comedic relief at the beginning of each episode. Seeing as the director of this show is Takuya Igarashi, director of Ouran High School Host Club, the comedic moments in this show makes sense.


That doesn’t mean they fit, because they don’t, but it makes sense as to why they exist in the show. Before I get back to why the mystery episodes aren’t very good, I need to address the comedy in this show.


The comedy is VERY hit or miss. It seems repetitive at first, but gets somewhat more diverse as more characters are introduced and we see new character interactions. One of the main running gags is based around the character, Dazai. Dazai, based on a writer in real life (like every other character in this show, which is something I forgot to mention even though it’s not that important), likes suicide and a lot of the early jokes revolve around this. 


Other jokes revolve around character interactions and reactions, but if you dislike the suicide jokes, you will really dislike the early jokes. I personally thought they were funny at first and got varied after a while, but I still felt that the joke was overused to an extent. 


Moving back to why the mystery episodes are bad, it’s because they just turn into info dumps at the end of the episode. I personally still found these episodes enjoyable, but they are flawed. There’s no way for the audience to actually figure out any of these “mysteries” (by the way I’m using quotes now because they’re barely mysteries) because we don’t see any info besides what’s introduced within 5 minutes of talking about the case.


In the show, it basically boils down to being at the right place at the right time, phrasing with how people say things, and a bit of plot convenience. The show technically follows the *echo voice* 10 commandments of writing mysteries *echo ends*, but it’s just poorly executed.


The actual purpose of these episodes are to introduce and develop side characters, which is actually done pretty well, but it feels like the actual mysteries were an afterthought. The other type of episode is the action oriented episode. These episodes are better, but still have their problems. For one, the Port Mafia as a whole. 


From the perspective of the audience, the mafia and the agency are seen as black and white, good and bad. We almost never see the mafia in a positive light, and even if we do, those scenes are still laced with negative connotations towards the Port Mafia. 


This seems pretty lazy as we get some interesting information about the mafia in relation to one of the main characters, but there’s just so much more that could have been done with this conflict. 


One last thing I want to mention with this show are its themes. Yes, this show actually has themes. It also has foil characters and a couple other literary terms I don’t feel like mentioning. This show has themes of loyalty and redemption. These two themes aren’t mind blowing, but it’s nice to see that there’s a little something to get out of it.


Also, the ED has some meaning to it, more than the OP, which was a nice touch and I’m glad it wasn’t just a black screen like… other shows of the season… *cough* RE:Zero *cough*


Characters


We actually get backstory for a couple of the characters in this show. Atsushi isn’t just some self-insert in this show and actually has a defined personality that somewhat changes as the show progresses. I mean, again, it isn’t ground breaking, but having it there adds to his character. He also gets a backstory too. 


His backstory makes sense in context to the story. He was exiled and hated as a child because of his power of turning into a weretiger, which is something I’m going to mention. This is basically victimization of his character for sympathy, but is excused in context to the story.


His power of turning into a weretiger, however, is not excused. He’s shown as not being able to control it, but when the plot demanded one time, he just got the ability to control it. 


If you know the context for this scene, because I don’t want to spoil the show, it could be seen that he got control over his powers in his desperation to help others, but it’s still cheap and unexplained. 


Moving onto the other main characters of this show, we have Dazai and Kunikida. Dazai is the only character in this series that has the slightest bit of grey with him. 


Compared to other characters in this show, he has a good backstory that has a really nice reveal. It wasn’t something I expected and I thought it added a lot to him. 


I just wish we got to see more of his past as there’s so much more I want to know. Hopefully we’ll learn more in season 2, but since this is a review of just season 1, I’m a little disappointed. Besides his backstory, he has 2 main character traits: His silly suicide mode for when the comedy ensues and his serious mode.


Sometimes he uses his suicide mode as a façade, which is something I thought was quite clever, but other times, it really ruins the mood of the moment.  The mood is something that really gets messed up because of these personality flips and I wish they had better transitions between the silly and serious. 


Kunikida is the always serious, super organized agency member. His scheduling method creeps into other aspects of his life and he is quite idealistic. He’s used as a direct mentor for Atsushi at first, then as a juxtaposed character to another character later on.


As a main character, he isn’t as strong in terms of personality because he doesn’t develop, likewise with Dazai. Atsushi and a couple side character are the only ones to get proper development, which is kind of disappointing. 


Overall, the characters are enjoyable, but they don’t all have the depth I would have liked. They have more effort put into them than a lot of other shows, but they aren’t the deepest characters. 


Sound and Animation


OH MY GOD the music of this show. If you don’t feel like watching this show at this point, at least watch episode 8 because it has the one of the greatest compilations of music in a single episode. 


The soundtrack is quite memorable and a lot of the tracks are quite 

distinguished. And again, episode 8. I can consistently jam out while episodes play out because the soundtrack is that good.


The music is composed by Taku Iwasaki, known most for shows like “Now and Then, Here and There”, Rurushi Kenshin, Akame ga kill, and Noragami. As you can see, this show has some talent behind it. 


The voice acting is also good and fits well. None of the voices feel out of place and characters emote well. If there’s one song in the OST I don’t really like, it’s the OP, but it’s still pretty decent. 


The art for this show is quite distinguished. It has a style that’s different from other shows of this season. I personally like the detail to the eyes in this show. 


The thick lines around characters in the comedic scenes really add a layer of uniqueness to the art style. This added with all the other little art style changes in the show really make this show stand out in terms of animation and art compare to your generic moeblob show of the season. 


The action scenes are especially something to note because they make up for the scenes that are somewhat… lacking. 


When there are closer shots, the faces are kind of… missing. You’d think they’d care a little more about the animation of faces, but it seems a little lazy in this aspect. 


Final Verdict


This show has its problems. It really does, but it also has another half to address some of these problems. It has comedy that’s hit or miss. The animation is great most of the time, but, like other shows, has its lacking moments. The story has progression, but no clear direction. Some characters have nice characterization, development, and backstories, but others just don’t have enough. The music is my favorite part of the show and really gets me hyped for watching each episode. 


There’s some deeper meaning and themes that I, as a person who looks at the effectiveness of literary device, can appreciate the little meaning they add to certain places. 


Overall, I think this show has more pros than cons, which is why I rate it a 6/10. If the second season gives more to the characters, development, and less mystery episodes it’ll be better overall. If you care to know my personal enjoyment score, it’s a 7.5/10 because I usually tried to watch these episodes right when they came out and got especially excited during the fight scenes, but I wasn’t screaming while episodes ran like some people I’ve seen.

I was very interested in Bungou Stray Dogs since I had seen many badass screen shots of the anime, so I had quite high expectations for it. But they were all shot down after I went to read few reviews of the anime before I started to watch it. Some liked it a lot, others not so much. I've seen many say that it's kind of a mess (at least this first season) and I have to agree with them. 
The story is interesting, don't get me wrong, but at least with this first season, it's feels as if it's standing on a weak ground- we don't really get to know about the universe that much. Though, like with many animes, you can't really blame them since this is the first season. There were some super weird moments but all in all, it does follow your basic anime tropes. 


Bones studio has their lows and highs with the art style. Though I have to say that BSD has the best art style out of the other animes from the studio that I've watched - at least consistency wise. The art style was actually one of the reasons why I was so intrigued by this anime in the first place. But please... no more of that fisheye lens shots... they're so ugly...  


Gotta be honest, didn't pay that much attention to the music, and I'm still not the biggest fan of the ending, but the opening was great!


As I stated before, I don't think you can blame them for showing only the minimal surface of the characters since this is the first season. Though there were some moments when the characters acted in a way I didn't think fit their characters but oh well. 


My enjoyment while watching this show was surprisingly high - I actually laughed out loud few times. Though the fact that they seem to kinda push this fourteen (14) year old girl to have romantic feelings towards an eighteen (18) year old boy is creepy and I was kinda uncomfortable every time they even hinted at it in your typical anime style. 


Overall, I did like this anime and I will watch the other season, and even read the manga. I think the story is interesting and I hope that it will become better.

I think this anime has a really interesting concept and the characters all seem to have some sort of potential. I don't have a whole lot to say as this anime is pretty obviously setting up for future seasons (which I know to exist cos season 3 is currently airing) as if this was a stand-alone it'd be pretty mediocre. However, it did a pretty good job of establishing the universe and giving some background to the main characters, enough to leave me wanting to know more. 
Also just a personal thing for me but Dazai kind of reminds me of Yato from Noragami, insanelystrong with dark history but still a dork with big bastard energy which I'm finding to be one of my new favourite character tropes.

Honestly I love this show. I don't think its amazing by all means the plot and such is fine and I wouldn't say the show is the anything special such as HunterxHunter or Erased, however, I love the characters and character dynamics in this show which is why I found so much enjoyment in it. Not to mention the concept is extremely fun. I am a big fan of classic literature and mobceterric stories as well as super powers so I also greatly enjoyed that aspect.
 If you're in the mood for fun character dynamics and an easy and cool concept I would highly recommendthis show. I got a lot of enjoyment and it's still one of my favorites despite having watched it almost a year or too ago, over all I really thick its worth the watch.

With thrilling action, quirky characters, and a bit of zany comedy, Bungou Stray Dogs is a great mix of excitement and hilarity.
[I must note that a second season will be airing in the Fall, so my thoughts here are based on the fact that the story will have a continuation.]
For the story, I'm unsure what to think of it. With what we got, it's simply different groups of organizations at each other's throats because they have their own ideals. Now, that's good and all, I don't really mind it, but I have this feeling that there should be something that gives us the "big picture"behind everything. If so, it just hasn't happened yet. What I will praise the show for is the writing. There's this odd mixture of seriousness and wacky comedy that somehow blends pretty well. I personally enjoy it, and believe it's what makes the show unique.


The best aspect of the show is the characters. We get a whole cast of personalities, and they all have enough time in the spotlight to where we can get a good read on them. And that last statement was an unintentional pun, as I should point out that the characters are all based on well-known authors. Even though a lot of these names I'm not familiar with, this is what drew me into the series. And what's great is there's more to them than their names; they shine when they need to and interact with each other nicely.


This was another series this season that did well with keeping up on the animation. Rarely did I see any flaws, and if so, they were probably so small I didn't realize. The animation also helps emphasize the comedy portions as the style and the character models change to match the mood. If it wasn't for that, I think the comedy wouldn't have gone over that well.


As I said, the thing that interest me was how the characters were depicting real-life authors. Yet I'm glad that wasn't the only thing that the series had going for it. It also makes we want to have a look at the original works these authors have written. Bungou Stray Dogs was a thoroughly enjoyable experience and it makes me excited for the second season (which, by the way, was announced before this season aired).

I only watched a few episodes because I really did not enjoy this anime. It wasn't awful, but it didn't seem worth my time. I'd watched this anime after seeing recommendations that it's good for people who like shows directed at more mature audiences. It's definitely not -- I'd recommend this more for high schoolers than anyone 18+.

The synopsis and good graphics is what encouraged me first to watch the series' 1st season.
What I like:
Graphics and voice acting - I really think the voices and art are well crafted. 
Comedic appeal - I expected a serious type of detective story but as it turned out, the script seemed to be more concerned with highlighting the characters' eccentric individuality rather than the complexity of the crimes. 
The comedy part is really a fresh breather for your typical mystery/detective story.
Touch of supernatural - Because you don't often get to see good-looking detectives who have supernatural powers. (this kind of reminds me of Hamatora)
What Idon't like:\n\n
The villains - I always pay attention to the villains since they play a great role in motivating the main characters. Sadly, the enemies in this story (so far) seemed to be so lame compared to our dear detectives.\n\n
Lack of intellectual thrill - I was looking forward to the creative and complex crime cases that the story could produce. But it just didn't happen. Perhaps on the 2nd season?\n\n
Generally though,  I would still recommend Bungou Stray Dogs not for those who want hardcore mystery and crime stories but rather those who wish to have a good laugh. \n\n
